Here lies, reduc'd to ashes and cinder,</br>No Sir Paul, but Sir Abraham Pindar.</br>It is not fierce Horatio Vere,</br>But Horatio Cowley buried here.
Nor is this Polydore Virgil's room,</br>But Cantabrigian Virgil's tomb.</br>The pleasant'st child e'er England bred</br>The bravest youth e're Cambridge fed</br>The dearest man e're wore a head.

Whilst that thy ballads up and down do flutter</br>And the town gallants of thy town muse mutter</br>Possesse this church, though thou couldst not the Savoy</br>And in her soft lap let Melpomene have thee.

Let no Court storm nor tough-lung'd zealot blow</br>Thy neatly angled atomes to and fro</br>And sleep in beggar's Limbo, by dull Chaucer,</br>Under the whim wham urn as broad as sawcer</br>Whilst that thy name doth smell as sweet as May's</br>And all the table talk is of thy Thais</br>Thy miscellany and thy Davideis.
Rot away here and let the vault endure thee</br>Let the religion of the house secure thee</br>And let the watching muses here immure thee.
Avaunt all ye that look profane and vile</br>Stand off, stand off, a hundred thousand mile</br>Nor with your thumbs this monument defile.
Let sugar-candy Cowley sleep in's grotte</br>Let not the people wake him, let them not</br>Nor steal away the surgeons gally pot.
Whilst on wing'd Pegasus thou [Phoebus Son]</br>Through air and earth and sea and all do ride</br>Whilst by Orinda's pipe thy praise is blown
Whilst thou dost soar aloft leave coyrs behind</br>To be interrd in antient monast'ry</br>And to the chimeing rabble safely joyn'd</br>
